front.title: Segment Routing IPv6 for Mobile User Plane

abstract.t: This document discusses the applicability of SRv6 (Segment Routing IPv6) to user-plane of mobile networks. The source routing capability and the network programming nature of SRv6 will accomplish the mobile user-plane functions quite straightforwardly. The statelessness and the ability to control underlying layer will be even more beneficial to the mobile user-plane, in terms of providing flexibility and SLA control for various applications. It also simplifies the network architecture by eliminating the necessity of tunnels, such as GTP, Mac-in-Mac, MPLS, and so on. In addition, Segment Routing can provide an enhanced method for network slicing, which will also be briefly touched by this document.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: In mobile networks, mobility management systems provide connectivity while mobile nodes move around. While the control-plane of the system signals movements of a mobile node, user-plane establishes tunnel between the mobile node and anchor node over IP based backhaul and core networks.

This document discusses the applicability of SRv6 (Segment Routing IPv6) to those mobile networks. SRv6 provides source routing to networks where operators can explicitly indicate a route for the packets from and to the mobile node. SRv6 endpoint nodes perform the roles of anchor of mobile user-plane.

section.title: Conventions and Terminology
section.t: The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in .
All segment routing and SRv6 network programming terms are defined in and .

section.title: Motivations
section.t: Current and future applications require a highly optimized data-path between mobile nodes and the entities of those applications in terms of latency, bandwidth, etc.,. However the current architecture of mobile management is agnostic about underlying topologies of transport layer. It rigidly fragments the user-plane into radio access, core and service networks and connects them by tunneling techniques through the user-plane roles such as access and anchor nodes. Such agnosticism and rigidness make it difficult for the operator to optimize the data-path.

While the mobile network industry has been trying to solve that problems, applications are shifting to use IPv6 data-path, and network operators adopt IPv6 as their IP transport as well. SRv6 integrates both application data-path and underlying transport layer in data-path optimizations that do not require any other techniques.

SRv6 source routing capability with programmable functions can fulfill the user-plane functions of mobility management. SRv6 takes advantage of underlying layer awareness and flexibility to deploy user-plane functions. Those are the motivations to adopt SRv6 for mobile user-plane.

section.title: Reference Architecture and Deployment Scenarios
section.t: This section describes a referene architecture and possile deployment scenarios.

shows a reference architecture, based on 5G packet core architecture . ?
UE : User Equipment gNB : gNodeB UPF : User Plane Function SMF : Session Management Function AMF : Access and Mobility Management Function DN : Data Network e.g. operator services, Internet access

A session from an UE gets assigned to an UPF. Sometimes more than one UPF can be used for providing a certain kind of richer service functions. UE gets its IP address from the DHCP block of its UPF. The UPF advertises the IP address block towards the Internet ensuring that return traffic is routed to the right UPF.
The deployment of SRv6 to the mobile dataplane will happen in phases, so this document assumes the following two scenarios.

section.title: Scenario1 : SRv6 on N3 and N9
section.t: In this scenario, it is assumed that both gNB and UPF are SRv6 nodes, thus SRv6 can be supported both on N3 and N9.
shows scenario1.

section.title: Scenario2 : IPv4 GTP on N3 and SRv6 on N9
section.t: In this scenario, it is assumed that gNB does not support SRv6. It just supports GTP encapsulation based on IPv4. Hence, SRv6 node interfacing with gNB should provide an interworking function (IWF) between GTP and SRv6.
shows scenario2, IPv4 GTP on N3 and SRv6 on N9.

section.title: Dataplane behaviors
section.t: This section describes the mobile dataplane behaviors using SRv6. The terminology for the functions enabled on the SRv6 node refers to .

There are two conceivable options in terms of the SRv6 SID allocation. One is "Traditional mode", which inherits the traditional mobile data plane, and another one is "Enhanced mode", which aggregates the mobile sessions and allocates SID per policy basis.

section.title: Traditional Mode
section.t: In the traditional mode, we assume that mobile user-plane functions are just as same as existing ones except the use of SRv6 as the data plane instead of GTP-U. No impact to the rest part of mobile system should be expected.

In the traditional mobile network, an UE session is mapped 1-for-1 with a specific GTP tunnel (TEID). This 1-for-1 mapping is replicated here as the sole pupose to replace the GTP encaps with the SRv6 encaps, while not changing anything else.

This mode is not likely to be considered for deploymet from the scalability point of view. But this model minimizes the changed required to the entire system and it is a good startpoint for forming the common basis.

section.title: Packet flow for Scenario1
section.t:
Refer to .
UE_out : (A,Z) gNB_out : (gNB, U1::1) -> T.Encaps.Reduced [U1::1] UPF1_out: (gNB, U2::1) -> END.MAP UPF2_out: (A,Z) -> END.DT
The UE packet arrives to the gNB. The gNB performs a T.Encaps.Reduced operations. Since there is only one SID, there is no need to push an SRH. gNB only puts an outer IPv6 header with IPv6 DA U1::1. U1::1 represents an anchoring SID specific for that session at UPF1. The SID U1::1 is retrived retrieved through a control plane.
Upon pacekt arrival on UPF1, the SID U1::1 is a local End.MAP SID. This function maps the SID with the next anchoring point and replaces the SID by U2::1, that belongs to the next anchoring point.
Upon packe arrival on UPF2, the SID U2::1 corresponds to an END.DT SID. It decapsulate the packet, peforms a lookup in a specific table and forward the packet towards the data network.
For the reverse path, the same functions apply.

For IPv6 user-traffic, a service provider can choose to do SRH insertion, instead of doing SRH encasulation, so that it would lower the overhead. In such case, the functions used are T.Insert, END.MAP and END.T.

section.title: Enhanced Mode
section.t:
This mode improves the scalability. In addition, it provides key improvements in terms of traffic steering and service chaining, thanks to the use of an SR policy of multiple SIDs, instead of single one in the Traditional mode.
Several UE share the same SR Policy (and composing SID) The SR policy MAY include SIDs for traffic steering and service chaining on top of the UPF anchor. The initiating SR node resovle the IP address into a SID list through a mechanism like reverse DNS, LISP, etc.

section.title: Packet flow for Scenario1
section.t: Refer to .

[Uplink]
UE_out : (A,Z) gNB_out : (gNB, S1) (gNB, S1; SL=2) (A,Z) -> T.Encaps.Reduced [S1, C1, U2::1] S1_out : (gNB, C1) (U2::1, S1; SL=1) (A,Z) C1_out : (gNB, U2::1) (A,Z) -> PSP UPF2_out: (A,Z) -> END.DT
UE sends its packet (A,Z) on a specific bearer session to its gNB. gNB's CP associates the session from the UE (A) with IPv6 address B and GTP TEID T. gNB's CP does a lookup on B (by reverseDNS, LISP, etc.) to find the related SID list [S1, C1, U2::1].

[Downlink]
[UPF2_in : (Z,A) -> UPF2 maps A with SID list [C1, S1, gNB] [UPF2_out: (U2::1, C1) (gNB, S1; SL=2) (Z,A) -> T.Encaps.Reduced [C1_out : (U2::1, S1) (gNB, S1; SL=1) (Z,A) [S1_out : (U2::1, gNB) (Z,A) -> PSP [gNB_out : (Z,A)

As a generic property of Segment Routing, the SIDs instantiated at UPF1 and UPf2 (U1::1 and U2::2) are shared among several UE sessions. This menas that for 1 million UEs, there will M T.Encaps operations and N U2::1 SIDS, where M and N scales in the likely tens or low-hundreds.

For IPv6 user-traffic, a service provider can choose to do SRH insertion, instead of doing SRH encasulation, so that it would lower the overhead. In such case, the functions used are T.Insert, END.MAP and END.T.

section.title: Packet flow for Scenario2
section.t:
Refer to .
In Scenario2, gNB is unchanged and encapsulates packets into GTP. Interwork Function (IFW) removes GTP, finds SID list related to DA, add SRH with SID list. The SR policy MAY include SIDs for traffic steering and service chaining on top of the UPF anchor, in commono with Scenario1.

UE gets an IP address (A) from its L3 anchor point (U2::1) UE sends its packet (A,Z) on a specific bearer session to its gNB. gNB's CP associates the session from the UE (A) with IPv6 address B and GTP TEID T.

[Uplink]
gNB_out : (gNB, B) (GTP: TEID T) (A,Z) -> Interface N3 unchanged IWF_out : (IWF, S1) (U2::1, S1; SL=1) (A,Z) -> New END.GTP.UP S1_out : (IWF, C1) (U2::1, C1; SL=1) (A,Z) C1_out : (gNB, U2::1) (A,Z) -> PSP UPF2_out: (A,Z) -> END.DT

[Downlink]
UPF2_in : (Z,A) -> UPF2 maps A with SID list [C1, S1, IWF::TEID, gNB] UPF2_out: (U2::1, C1) (gNB, IWF::TEID, S1; SL=3) (Z,A) -> T.Encaps.Reduced C1_out : (U2::1, S1) (gNB, S1; SL=2) (Z,A) S1_out : (U2::1, IWF::TEID) (gNB, IWF::TEID, S1, SL=1) (Z,A) gNB_out : (Z,A)
For the downlink traffic, the IWF is stateless. All the state is in the SRH imposed by the UPF. The UPF must have this UE-Base state anyway since it's the anchor point.

For the uplink traffic, the state at the IWF is shared, not dedicated on a per UE/session basis. Hence, the states likely scale in the low 10/100s and this is more scalable compared to the millions of sessions.

For IPv6 user-traffic, a service provider can choose to do SRH insertion, instead of doing SRH encasulation, so that it would lower the overhead. In such case, the functions used are T.Insert, END.MAP and END.T.

section.title: Network Slicing Considerations
section.t: A mobile network may be required to implement "network slices", which logically separate network resources. User-plane functions represented as SRv6 segments would be part of a slice.

A simple way to represent slice would be to apply L2/L3vpn described in . Segment Routing with [IGP flex algo] would provide even more advanced separation based on metrics like link-delay Thus, a service provider would be able to have network slices per required SLA.
The SRv6 SID and quite a few SR extended capability would be a powerful tool for providing logical separation/integration within a network. Details are for further study.

section.title: Control Plane Considerations
section.t: This documents focuse on the dataplane behavior. The control planes could be based on the existing 3GPP based signaling, LISP/ILSR, DNS/reverse DNS lookup, MFA, etc., and to be discussed further.
It's notable that SRv6's network programming nature allows a flexible and dynamic anchor placement.
